In this scenario you must guide your Medieval civilization through the infamous Black Death, keeping its cultural and scientific efforts alive as the population suffers death and despair. To win, you must unlock either the final Technology (Invention) or the final Civic (The Middle Class), sowing the seed of the Enlightenment to come.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]THE PLAGUE[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Over 85 turns the Black Death will sweep across the continent in waves. It originates in port cities in every nation and spreads outward across the landscape. It can spread to any land tile except Mountains, and will spread more easily to cities, roads, Coasts that contain Harbor districts, and rural improvements. When the plague arrives in a tile it becomes [COLOR:Red]Plague-Stricken[ENDCOLOR] for a number of turns. When the turns are up the tile will recover, but while plague-stricken it suffers the following effects:[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR:Red][ICON_BULLET]Plague-stricken tiles cannot be worked by citizens, cannot be improved or repaired, and cannot be used to construct districts or add buildings if a district already exists[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]If the tile is a city center, there is a high chance one population will die each turn the plague remains. This chance can be reduced by constructing certain buildings or using certain government policies[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Units that end their turn on a plague-stricken tiles suffer 20 damage[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]To combat the Black Death, look to preserve your cities' power to keep working through the calamity. Build essential districts while your citizens are able. Keep your [ICON_Gold] Gold and [ICON_Faith] Faith reserves high to purchase buildings and units when your cities are crippled. Establish centers of science and culture early and protect them as best you can. When Plague Doctors become available, use them to safeguard your most vulnerable areas or shore up the Loyalty of cities that are wavering.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Difficulty affects [ICON_GOLD] Gold and [ICON_FAITH] Faith.

Wealthy landowners blame the miasma - putrid fumes that abound in the dense cities - for the deadly disease. They are fleeing in droves to their country estates, taking their retainers with them and leaving the streets for the poor and homeless.
Fear is driving some populations towards your cities and others away from them. New Policies allow you to choose which to support.

Many claim to have the power or the knowledge to stop the plague. But whether charlatans, priests, physicians or kings, the plague defies them all. The people are distraught and desperate for answers.
New Policies allow you take more drastic measures to ease the public mind.
The plague and its grisly harvest cover the land. Everywhere your people turn, death confronts them. What is the use of striving when high and low, wealthy and poor are struck down alike?

The disease is sweeping the nation, overturning the stability and traditions our society has relied on for decades. Those in power set the example of how to react to the crumbling social order.

As the death toll rises, the people seek aid from the authorities they trust. Many plead that science has the key and wish to hire physicians to attend the afflicted. Others are driven to fanaticism and demand atonement to beseech God to stop the plague.
The death toll swells beyond all imagining. Faith in the church and the state alike are crumbling as despair sets in. Society cannot continue as it has - a break must come.

The dead fill the cities and overwhelm the graveyards. Even the most conservative witness the devastation and wonder if the world's wickedness has finally earned divine retribution.

Prior to the Black Death, there was a flourishing of learning and education in Europe, and the rise of the university meant a new class of educated professional devoted to study. Some scholars focused on practical affairs like law, but a growing group turned to questions of the nature of knowledge and natural philosophy, paving the way for the early Renaissance.

One of the most striking figures of the Black Death is the plague doctor, with his macabre beak-shaped mask, long robes, and staff. The tip of the beak mask would contain a sachet of aromatic herbs (the sweet smell was erroneously thought to repel the plague). A plague doctor would be called in when a patient (or dead body) was suspected of contracting the plague. He would use his stick or staff to search the patient without touching them in order to certify the case or clear the patient.

In the religiously-charged world of the late Middle Ages, the plague was thought to be a divine punishment for the sins of humanity. Some groups of people undertook acts of extreme public penitence on behalf of a sinful humanity, processing across the land and whipping—or “flagellating”—themselves, from which practice derives the name. At first, these exhibitions had the (at least tacit) consent of the church authorities, but as the practice became extreme, the ecclesiastical authorities condemned it. This did not end the practice of flagellation, nor the processions of the flagellants.

One of the religious orders of knighthood in Europe, the Teutonic Knights conducted the Northern Crusade against the pagan tribes in the Baltic region. They were particularly noted for their aggressiveness, their intransigence, their wealth, and their austere lifestyle, even by the standards of crusader orders.

Without a proper understanding of the epidemiology of the plague, residents of cities nonetheless discovered a system for containing the Black Death: Walling off the victims in a permanent quarantine. This draconian measure doomed the walled-off victims to a terrible fate but could occasionally check the progress of the plague. It is an example of the terrible calculus of suffering in the Black Death that some healthy people willingly accepted quarantine rather than see the pestilence spread.

A guildhall is a semi-public building owned by a guild to provide a meeting space for the members as well as demonstrate their wealth and power. They were often ornately decorated as a powerful expression of civic and trade pride.

As the death tolls climbed during the Black Death, individual funerals were impractical, and dead bodies were buried in large numbers with whatever modesty could be provided for the dead. Sometimes partially decomposed bodies would be exhumed and reburied together to save space. In other cases, cemeteries became so clogged that the dead were buried above ground. Not all mass graves were marked, and they continue to be discovered in the present age.

Cities attempted to treat the plague victims as best they could, or at least attempt to minimize their suffering. Plague hospitals may have provided dubious care at best, but at least they provided a measure of hope to their patients that someone cared for them.

The central part of a castle or fortification, used as a holdout and last line of defense should the outer walls be breached. Keeps often have very few and very narrow entrances, so that a handful of defenders can still hold off invaders.

Several factors affected improvements in civil engineering during the Medieval period including the importance of building strong castles, the importance of sieging these castles, and the need to build cities capable of holding large populations without wallowing in their own waste.
Skilled artisans and artists began to rediscover systems and technologies known in the classical world. With so many deaths during the Black Plague, labor-saving machines became more important.

Medicine is the practical art of balancing the humors of the body -- blood, phlegm, black bile, and yellow bile -- as laid out in Hippocrates. It may include the study of astrology (as the heavenly bodies influence these humors) and the four primary elements: Fire, earth, air, and water. It is a suitable course of study for those persons incapable of full appreciation of the sublime disciplines like logic and theology.

The shortage of workers after the Black Death led to a decline in the traditional systems of serfdom in Europe. Now, agricultural and other workers could expect to be paid wages for their work instead of having it compelled from them.

The rediscovery of Roman Law texts in the Middle Ages led to the growth of the University system in cities like Bologna and Paris. Education became broadly accessible outside of the church and laid the foundation for the Renaissance.

The shortage of workers after the deaths of the Black Plague raised the value of labor. No longer could nobles simply beat the peasants into working the land, as those ingrates would simply go to serve a new lord, who would pay them in coin.

The rise of cities in Europe meant the rise of a new class outside of the traditional aristocrats-ecclesiastics-peasantry model of the feudal world. Most rulers saw them as a useful tax base for funding wars.
Fealty is the process of swearing allegiance to a master in a feudal system, such as a knight swearing to serve a baron, or that baron swearing service to a king.

The rise of cities meant that along with gatherings of merchants and skilled tradesmen, there rose a class of individuals whose social standing was judged to be inferior or unwanted because they did not fit neatly into social norms of the feudal period. Arguably these attitudes extend into the present age.

The original name for the university, or the education given at the university, meaning “general studies.” Unlike the seven liberal arts, there was no defined curriculum for the Studia, which necessitated universities to offer the diploma as recognition that a student had successfully studied and might have learned something.

A cottage industry is a small business set up by an individual or family either to support themselves or provide supplementary income. These small enterprises are generally considered to be part of the transition from feudal economies to market-based economies.

Skilled trades or arts can only be mastered through long practice, especially the production of valuable goods like silverware, cloth, glassware, and machinery. Tradespeople would congregate in cities where they could work in concert, training future practitioners, setting prices, and trying to control the market for their goods. Skilled tradespeople were some of the first true middle-class citizens in history.

The growing notion that states were political entities beyond their rulers led to the growth of a class of servants who expressed their duty in terms of service to the state, not its ruler. This allowed them to dispassionately serve the good of the state but did not make them any more popular when it came time to collect taxes.

When manufacturing complex objects, having individuals focus on one aspect of the production allows for a higher rate of production than having a single artisan work a piece from material through completion. Many objects were built in this fashion through the Middle Ages and the Early Modern period, including weapons and armor. The rise of specialization would eventually find fuller expression in the Industrial Age and the assembly line.
Groups of merchants would band together to exercise greater economic power. These commercial leagues would eventually provide the basis for the modern systems of banking and currency.
At one point a labor market was literally a place in the marketplace where unskilled laborers would congregate, waiting to be hired for a given job. It still is that in some places.
Quarantine is the isolation of sick people to prevent the spread of a disease through the population. Yellow flags have been used to mark quarantined places since the Black Death.

From the Russian word meaning “to destroy,” a pogrom is the systematic murder and oppression of a group with the approval of the state. The oppressed group is usually a minority, such as the Jews in Europe for most of European history. The justification is usually a libel for some crime they did not commit. Pogroms have a long and awful history, and have happened entirely too many times, despite people solemnly swearing “and this shall never happen again” after each one occurs.

The practice of directly supporting another’s work is called patronage. Patronage can be a conspicuous identifier of wealth, or it can be conducted for truly selfless reasons. Many great works of art and literature were done at the behest of wealthy patrons.

Literally “The nobility provides,” the expression means that persons of greater social standing and means should be generous and provide to those with less. Un-asked-for charity is not always received with the deferential humility expected by the giver.

Philip VI was the first French king of the Valois dynasty, whose reign is defined by the start of the Hundred Years’ War with England. One his first acts was to suppress a rebellion in Flanders and re-seat Count Louis. His relations with Edward III of England began well, but deteriorated over the status of the Duchy of Aquitaine and whether or not Edward was Philip’s vassal. This and other matters were some of the precipitating instances of the Hundred Years’ War.

While Philip held Edward to a grinding war of raid and attrition, he held advantage due to the wealth of France, but open and decisive battle proved more favorable to the English. After the Battle of Crecy in 1346, the French nobility and their allies were so badly decimated that the Estates of France refused to pay for any more wars. The arrival of the Black Death in 1348 was every bit as destructive, and deaths included Queen Joan, his wife.

Perhaps England’s most successful medieval king, his 50-year reign was marked by wars, the rise of Parliament, and the plague. His father, Edward II, was overthrown when Edward III was only a child, but Edward quickly moved to exercise rule in his own right.

Waging wars against Scotland and France, Edward III and his subordinate commanders (particularly his eldest son, Edward the Black Prince) were responsible for many of the greatest English victories of the Hundred Years’ War, including the naval battle at Sluys. Edward III himself commanded the troops at the Battle of Crecy, where English longbowmen slaughtered the flower of French nobility in an afternoon.

The Black Death of 1361 marks the decline and twilight of his reign. Plague death deprived him of the resources needed to fight his wars, and rising social tensions at home occupied him for much of the rest of his life.

Known as Alfonso the Just, he was king of Castile and Leon, inheriting the throne from his father, Ferdinand IV when he was just a year old. Upon coming to age in 1325, he successfully squashed the squabbling (and the power) of the noble families, instituted important legal reforms in the Ordinances of Alcala de Hernares, and waged war against the Marinid Berbers, winning an important victory over them at the Battle of Salado River in Andalusia.
Alfonso died of the Black Death during a siege of Gibraltar in 1350, and reign passed to his son, Peter the Cruel.

Louis the Bavarian, the Holy Roman Emperor was the first Wittelsbach emperor of the Germans. His early reign was marked by struggles against both the Habsburg and Luxembourg families and their claimants for the imperial crown. This conflict spilled over into an ancillary conflict with the pope, who excommunicated Louis as a heretic. This proved somewhat awkward when Louis was crowned Emperor in Rome in 1328 by the Roman population. Louis’ reign as emperor was eventually secured mostly as a result of the death of his rivals and general exhaustion in the empire over the endless succession schemes of the major houses.

Allied with Edward III of England, he was into opposition with France (and the Pope in Avignon), which exacerbated his political situation at home. At the time of his death near Munich in 1347, he had failed to establish the Wittelsbachs as a dominant house in Imperial politics.

The greatest political body in Central Europe at the time of the Black Death was a polyglot, multiethnic collection of kingdoms, principalities, bishoprics, duchies, free cities, contested lands, baronies, and parishes, all notionally under the secular rule of the Emperor. Powerful ruling families and the Pope were often vying for effective control or autonomy for their own territories.

The region of Castile occupies much of the central area of today’s nation of Spain. During the Medieval Age, the kingdom was usually at war with the Muslim regions in southern Spain. The unification of the crowns of Castile and the neighboring kingdom of Leon would set the stage for Castile to become the dominant power in the Iberian Peninsula.

The Plantagenet family that ruled England during the Black Death had claims to both the English and French thrones. They had embarked on military conquests against Scotland and Wales. Over time, the king of England was forced to accede power to Parliament and the nobility, meaning that English kings were comparatively less powerful than other European monarchs.

During the Medieval Age, France was one of the richest and most prosperous regions of Europe. At this time, the kings of France directly held a substantial amount of territory under their direct control, making them among the most centralized kingdoms of this era.
